awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Othello Hashing and Its Applications to Scalable and Dynamic Network Forwarding and Functions
awd_abstract_narration:
Providing high-speed Internet services to communities and businesses while limiting the infrastructure cost has been a long-term goal of network protocol designs. There have been challenges in achieving fast, scalable, and fine-grained network processing while maintaining low network cost, mainly due to the limited resources on network devices such as fast memory.  The promising approach of exploiting programmable networks, such as software defined networking, were considered difficult to execute on conventional network devices. This project aims to use an innovative hashing scheme, Othello, to improve network performance without special and expensive hardware by exploring fast, memory-efficient, and portable primitives for network processing based on innovative data structures and algorithms. 

This project proposes Othello Hashing, a key-value lookup algorithm developed on the theoretical foundation of Minimal Perfect Hashing. Othello Hashing achieves faster lookup speed and much smaller memory cost compared to existing network lookup methods. It utilizes network programmability to support dynamic updates on its lookup structures. This project plans to develop a number of important network primitives using Othello, including forwarding information bases, software load balancers, distributed data placement, and private data access. The success of this project will demonstrate Othello Hashing as a fundamental tool in designing novel network algorithms, protocols, and systems, for which existing tools may not be suitable. The impact of Othello Hashing may go beyond the networking research: the collaboration of the PI with genome biology researchers on applying Othello to metagenomic sequence classification has led to promising results. The project also offers a number of education activities for student training, undergraduate research participation, diversity promotion, and outreach activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to study fast and memory-efficient network data structures and algorithms to eliminate the speed or memory bottleneck of network packet processing on generalized computing devices. We propose two new mechanisms called Othello and Ludo hashing, on the theoretical basis of minimal perfect hashing. They are designed with a number of unique properties, which can fit the requirements of the core algorithms and data structures of many network forwarding and network function tasks.

 

The outcomes of this project include:

 

1. We designed and implemented a scalable and memory-efficient forwarding information base with fast lookups.

2. We designed and implemented a fast and light-weighted software load balancer, named Concury.

3. We proposed a collaborative validation of public-key certificates for IoT using Othello-based caching.

4. We developed SeqOthello, a novel indexing structure that supports query of an arbitrary sequence against large collections of RNA-seq experiments.

5. We designed vacuum filters, a data structure for approximate membership queries (AMQ) to overcome the limitations of cuckoo filters.

6. We used Othello for certificate revocation checking on memory-limited IoT devices. We designed and implemented an on-device CR checking system called TinyCR.

7. We conducted research to provide a novel solution called Smash to achieve both placement flexibility while maintaining cost-effectiveness and scalability for distributed storage.

 

We published a number of journal and conference papers in highly selective venues including ACM SIGCOMM, ACM MobiCom, ACM CCS, ACM SIGMETRICS, IEEE INFOCOM, IEEE ICNP, and IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking. Four PhD students have been supported by this project. Three have successfully graduated. The other student under this project has passed the PhD qualifying exam. Two REU students have been supported by this project.

 

The PI developed both graduate and undergraduate system and networking courses that are closely related to this project. The PI has taught the trends and new challenges in designing new data structures and algorithms for fast in-network processing. In addition, the development of SeqOthello will enable labs with limited resources to learn from sequencing-level data by supporting fast and memory-efficient query over large-scale RNA-seq datasets.
